case_vignette:
A 25-year-old man comes to the physician for the evaluation of recurrent episodes of nosebleeds over the past 6 months. The nosebleeds occur spontaneously and stop after 10 minutes after pinching the nose at the nostrils. He has no history of serious illness except for prolonged bleeding following wisdom teeth extraction 2 years ago. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. He takes no medications. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination of the nose shows no abnormalities. There are several bruises on the lower extremities. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 15 g/dL
Leukocyte count 6,000/mm3
Platelet count 220,000/mm3
Bleeding time 9 minutes
Prothrombin time 13 sec
Partial thromboplastin time 55 sec
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?"

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Hematology and Oncology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been having recurrent nosebleeds for the past 6 months that happen spontaneously and usually stop after I pinch my nose for 10 minutes.
Have you had any other symptoms such as headaches, dizziness, or difficulty breathing through your nose?
No, I have not experienced any headaches, dizziness, or difficulty breathing through my nose.
Have you had any recent injuries or trauma to your nose?
No, I haven't had any recent injuries or trauma to my nose.
Have you had any allergies or infections in the past?
I have no history of serious illness, so no significant allergies or infections in the past.
Have you had any family history of bleeding disorders or autoimmune diseases?
I haven't mentioned anything about my family's medical history.
Have you been taking any medications or supplements recently?
No, I'm not taking any medications or supplements.
Have you had any recent changes in your diet or lifestyle?
No, I haven't made any recent changes to my diet or lifestyle.
Have you had any recent travel history?
I haven't mentioned anything about recent travel.
Have you had any recent stressful events or changes in your life?
I haven't mentioned experiencing any recent stressful events or changes in my life.
Have you had any recent surgeries or procedures?
Aside from having my wisdom teeth extracted 2 years ago, where I experienced prolonged bleeding, I haven't mentioned any other recent surgeries or procedures.
Have you had any recent blood tests or medical evaluations?
Yes, I've had some laboratory studies done recently.
What were the results of those laboratory studies?
My hemoglobin is 15 g/dL, leukocyte count is 6,000/mm3, platelet count is 220,000/mm3, bleeding time is 9 minutes, prothrombin time is 13 seconds, and partial thromboplastin time is 55 seconds.

Based on your symptoms and laboratory results, it is possible that you may have a bleeding disorder such as von Willebrand disease or hemophilia. These conditions can cause spontaneous bleeding and may require further evaluation and treatment. It is important to consult with a healthcare professional for a proper diagnosis and treatment plan.

Final Diagnosis: Bleeding Disorder

trial_0.summarized_conversation: The patient has been experiencing recurrent nosebleeds for the past 6 months that happen spontaneously and usually stop after pinching the nose for 10 minutes. There have been no associated headaches, dizziness, or difficulty breathing through the nose. The patient denies any recent injuries or trauma to the nose and has no history of serious illness, significant allergies, or infections. The patient has not mentioned anything about the family's medical history, medications, supplements, recent changes to diet or lifestyle, recent travel, or recent stressful events or changes in life. Aside from having wisdom teeth extracted 2 years ago with prolonged bleeding, the patient has had some laboratory studies done recently. The results indicate a hemoglobin of 15 g/dL, leukocyte count of 6,000/mm3, platelet count of 220,000/mm3, bleeding time of 9 minutes, prothrombin time of 13 seconds, and partial thromboplastin time of 55 seconds.
trial_0.vignette_frq: The most likely diagnosis is Hemophilia A.
trial_0.summarized_frq: The most likely diagnosis is epistaxis (nosebleed) with a possible underlying cause of idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP).
